text:
This is an extreme case and I doubt many people would encounter the problem, but
for large test cases with 50K or more URL's JMeter has difficulty loading the
file. Running large test cases is only feasible in nongui mode, since the test
case file could be 45+ megs. I had a couple thoughts on how the problem might be
tackled.

1. pre-parse the test case and compile the http requests to a temp directory.

2. rather than load the whole test case, the file could be separated into
multiple files. One file would contain the minimal information and the other
files would contain the actual request nodes. This way, the test case can be
loaded, but not the actual requests. The first file would link to the file
containing the request nodes.

3. set a limit on the number of requests to load and pre-fetch. it would mean
jmeter would have to keep track of which line it loaded last.

4. create n number of temporary cache and break the test case into chunks.
Similar to how vim loads large files.

For now I can get around the "outofmemory error" by running jmeter from a box
with lots of memory. One other option is to have a Generic random URL generator,
which can take n valid values and generate random URL's. There are occasions
when I want to do really large tests with 100K urls, so there must be others who
have the need.
